title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with specific duties. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," is tasked with studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It will consider the amount of money spent on campaigns, disclosure of funds, and whether current laws encourage qualified individuals to seek office. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996," will study laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It will assess the impact of campaign financing, disclosure of funds, rules governing media access for candidates, and other relevant matters. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 9 private sector members appointed by various leaders, with a chairperson selected within 7 days. The Commission shall consist of 9 private sector members appointed by various leaders, with a chairperson selected within 7 days through majority vote. If the chairperson is not selected within 30 days, all current members will be discharged. Vacancies in the Commission will be filled promptly. Each member of the Commission will be discharged if the chairperson is not selected within 30 days. Vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members are entitled to compensation based on the Executive Schedule. Six members constitute a quorum for decision-making. The Commission requires six members for a quorum and decisions need the affirmative vote of 6 members. Meetings are called by the chairperson or at the request of 6 members. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION; SERVICES. The chairperson can appoint necessary staff without following certain regulations. SEC. 6. RECOMMENDATION; FAST TRACK PROCEDURES. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. The report may include recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns, agreed upon by 6 or more members. If 7 or more members agree on recommendations for campaign changes, they can prepare bills for consideration. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. Recommendations for changes in Federal campaign conduct agreed upon by 6 or more members will be prepared as bills for expedited consideration by Congress. The Commission will cease to exist 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for carrying out the Act.
